english_definition: To kill; a transitive verb used for causing death (literal or figurative).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>虫<rt>むし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>殺<rt>ころ</rt></ruby>したくないと<ruby>言<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He said he doesn't want to kill insects.

english_definition: To spoil, damage, or impair; also used in patterns like 〜損なう to mean “fail to (do)” or “do badly.”
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>信頼<rt>しんらい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>損<rt>そこな</rt></ruby>うようなことはしない。
english_example: She won't do anything that would damage trust.

english_definition: Past form of 〜損ねる attached to a verb: “failed to (do)”; here, “failed to kill.”
japanese_example: <ruby>男<rt>おとこ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>相手<rt>あいて</rt></ruby>を<ruby>殺<rt>ころ</rt></ruby>し<ruby>損<rt>そこ</rt></ruby>ねて、<ruby>逃<rt>に</rt></ruby>げられた。
english_example: The man failed to kill his target, and they got away.

english_definition: To strike or hit (something); a basic verb used for physical blows and some set phrases.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>机<rt>つくえ</rt></ruby>をこぶしで<ruby>打<rt>う</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He struck the desk with his fist.

english_definition: To smash or crush into pieces; often used for breaking hard things or figuratively “to break down.”
japanese_example: <ruby>氷<rt>こおり</rt></ruby>を<ruby>砕<rt>くだ</rt></ruby>いて、<ruby>飲<rt>の</rt></ruby>み<ruby>物<rt>もの</rt></ruby>に<ruby>入<rt>い</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: I crushed ice and put it into the drink.

english_definition: Passive form meaning “to be shattered/crushed,” often used for hopes, confidence, or plans being destroyed.
japanese_example: <ruby>期待<rt>きたい</rt></ruby>は<ruby>一瞬<rt>いっしゅん</rt></ruby>で<ruby>打<rt>う</rt></ruby>ち<ruby>砕<rt>くだ</rt></ruby>かれた。
english_example: My hopes were shattered in an instant.

english_definition: Past passive: “was shattered/crushed”; commonly used for dreams, pride, expectations, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>自信<rt>じしん</rt></ruby>はその<ruby>言葉<rt>ことば</rt></ruby>で<ruby>打<rt>う</rt></ruby>ち<ruby>砕<rt>くだ</rt></ruby>かれた。
english_example: His confidence was crushed by those words.

english_definition: Thus; in this way; used to connect events and show the manner/result of what follows.
japanese_example: <ruby>話<rt>はなし</rt></ruby>し<ruby>合<rt>あ</rt></ruby>いを<ruby>重<rt>かさ</rt></ruby>ね、<ruby>こうして</ruby><ruby>計画<rt>けいかく</rt></ruby>が<ruby>決<rt>き</rt></ruby>まった。
english_example: After many discussions, this is how the plan was decided.

english_definition: Maternal side; used for relatives or lineage on one’s mother’s side (contrast: 父方).
japanese_example: <ruby>母方<rt>ははがた</rt></ruby>の<ruby>祖母<rt>そぼ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>北海道<rt>ほっかいどう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>住<rt>す</rt></ruby>んでいる。
english_example: My grandmother on my mother's side lives in Hokkaido.

english_definition: Husband and wife; a married couple as a unit.
japanese_example: あの<ruby>夫婦<rt>ふうふ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>毎朝<rt>まいあさ</rt></ruby><ruby>一緒<rt>いっしょ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>散歩<rt>さんぽ</rt></ruby>する。
english_example: That couple takes a walk together every morning.

english_definition: To raise or bring up (someone/something); transitive (contrast: 育つ intransitive).
japanese_example: <ruby>両親<rt>りょうしん</rt></ruby>は<ruby>子供<rt>こども</rt></ruby>を<ruby>大切<rt>たいせつ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>育<rt>そだ</rt></ruby>てた。
english_example: My parents raised their children with care.

english_definition: To grow up or be raised; intransitive (contrast: 育てる transitive).
japanese_example: <ruby>この町<rt>このまち</rt></ruby>で<ruby>育<rt>そだ</rt></ruby>った<ruby>人<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>は<ruby>地元<rt>じもと</rt></ruby>への<ruby>愛着<rt>あいちゃく</rt></ruby>が<ruby>強<rt>つよ</rt></ruby>い。
english_example: People who grew up in this town have a strong attachment to it.

english_definition: To spend (time) or live through (a period); often used with time expressions.
japanese_example: <ruby>週末<rt>しゅうまつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>でゆっくり<ruby>過<rt>す</rt></ruby>ごした。
english_example: I spent the weekend relaxing at home.

english_definition: First; the beginning; used for the initial point in a sequence or process.
japanese_example: <ruby>最初<rt>さいしょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>難<rt>むずか</rt></ruby>しかったが、だんだん<ruby>慣<rt>な</rt></ruby>れてきた。
english_example: It was difficult at first, but I gradually got used to it.

japanese: ハリーは自分ではそんな気はないのに
hiragana: はりーはじぶんではそんなきはないのに
english: even though Harry doesn’t feel that way
english_definition: Phrase meaning “Even though Harry himself doesn’t feel that way”; 〜のに expresses contradiction: despite X, Y happens.
japanese_example: <ruby>ハリー</ruby>は<ruby>自分<rt>じぶん</rt></ruby>ではそんな<ruby>気<rt>き</rt></ruby>はないのに、みんなに<ruby>怒<rt>おこ</rt></ruby>っていると<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>われた。
english_example: Even though Harry himself didn't feel that way, everyone thought he was angry.

english_definition: Often; frequently; casual adverb meaning something happens repeatedly.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>しょっちゅう</ruby><ruby>遅刻<rt>ちこく</rt></ruby>して<ruby>注意<rt>ちゅうい</rt></ruby>される。
english_example: He is frequently late and gets warned.

english_definition: An event or incident; something that happened (often notable).
japanese_example: <ruby>昨日<rt>きのう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>出来事<rt>できごと</rt></ruby>は<ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>でも<ruby>忘<rt>わす</rt></ruby>れられない。
english_example: I still can't forget what happened yesterday.

english_definition: To cause or bring about (often an event/problem); transitive and fairly formal.
japanese_example: <ruby>不注意<rt>ふちゅうい</rt></ruby>が<ruby>大<rt>おお</rt></ruby>きな<ruby>事故<rt>じこ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>引<rt>ひ</rt></ruby>き<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>こすことがある。
english_example: Carelessness can cause a serious accident.

english_definition: A mystery; strange or wondrous (noun/な-adjective), used for things that feel inexplicable.
japanese_example: <ruby>不思議<rt>ふしぎ</rt></ruby>なことに、<ruby>鍵<rt>かぎ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>急<rt>きゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>つかった。
english_example: Strangely enough, the key suddenly turned up.

japanese: 自分でも不思議に思っていた
hiragana: じぶんでもふしぎにおもっていた
english_definition: Phrase meaning “even he himself found it strange”; 不思議に思う = to find (something) mysterious/strange.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>自分<rt>じぶん</rt></ruby>でも<ruby>不思議<rt>ふしぎ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>っていたほど、<ruby>急<rt>きゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>運<rt>うん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>良<rt>よ</rt></ruby>くなった。
english_example: His luck improved so suddenly that even he himself found it strange.

english_definition: Automobile; a general term for motor vehicles (often contrasted with 自転車).
japanese_example: <ruby>自動車<rt>じどうしゃ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>通勤<rt>つうきん</rt></ruby>する<ruby>人<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>が<ruby>増<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>えている。
english_example: More people are commuting by car.

english_definition: Bicycle; a pedal-powered vehicle (often contrasted with 自動車).
japanese_example: <ruby>駅<rt>えき</rt></ruby>まで<ruby>自転車<rt>じてんしゃ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>く。
english_example: I go to the station by bicycle.

english_definition: An accident; commonly used for traffic accidents, incidents, and mishaps.
japanese_example: <ruby>交差点<rt>こうさてん</rt></ruby>で<ruby>事故<rt>じこ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>きて、<ruby>道<rt>みち</rt></ruby>が<ruby>混<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: An accident happened at the intersection, and the road got congested.

english_definition: To be able to/can; also “to be completed/made.” Meaning depends on context and the subject.
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>早<rt>はや</rt></ruby>く<ruby>帰<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>ることが<ruby>できる</ruby>。
english_example: Today I can go home early.

english_definition: However; and yet; used to introduce an unexpected turn or contrast to what was just said.
japanese_example: <ruby>簡単<rt>かんたん</rt></ruby>だと<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>った。<ruby>ところが</ruby>、<ruby>実際<rt>じっさい</rt></ruby>にやると<ruby>難<rt>むずか</rt></ruby>しかった。
english_example: I thought it would be easy. However, when I actually did it, it was difficult.

english_definition: Exactly; just; used for precise timing/amount or when something happens at the perfect moment.
japanese_example: <ruby>ちょうど</ruby><ruby>昼休<rt>ひるやす</rt></ruby>みの<ruby>時間<rt>じかん</rt></ruby>に<ruby>電話<rt>でんわ</rt></ruby>がかかってきた。
english_example: A call came in right during my lunch break.

english_definition: Suffix meaning “addressed to”; used in names/labels like 〜宛 (contrast with 〜向け ‘intended for’).
japanese_example: <ruby>部長<rt>ぶちょう</rt></ruby><ruby>宛<rt>あて</rt></ruby>の<ruby>書類<rt>しょるい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>受付<rt>うけつけ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>預<rt>あず</rt></ruby>けた。
english_example: I left the documents addressed to the manager at reception.

english_definition: “A letter addressed to Harry”; 宛 marks the addressee, used on envelopes and labels.
japanese_example: <ruby>ハリー</ruby><ruby>宛<rt>あて</rt></ruby>の<ruby>手紙<rt>てがみ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>机<rt>つくえ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>上<rt>うえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>置<rt>お</rt></ruby>いてあった。
english_example: A letter addressed to Harry was left on the desk.

english_definition: To arrive or be delivered; intransitive (something reaches you).
japanese_example: <ruby>注文<rt>ちゅうもん</rt></ruby>した<ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby><ruby>届<rt>とど</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: The package I ordered arrived today.

english_definition: Came to light; became public/known (often about secrets, wrongdoing, or hidden facts).
japanese_example: <ruby>不正<rt>ふせい</rt></ruby>が<ruby>明<rt>あか</rt></ruby>るみに<ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>て、<ruby>会社<rt>かいしゃ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>謝罪<rt>しゃざい</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The misconduct came to light, and the company apologized.

english_definition: Entering a school; admission/enrollment (often used with 〜する).
japanese_example: <ruby>妹<rt>いもうと</rt></ruby>は<ruby>春<rt>はる</rt></ruby>に<ruby>大学<rt>だいがく</rt></ruby>に<ruby>入学<rt>にゅうがく</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: My younger sister entered university in the spring.

english_definition: End of the school term/semester; often used when talking about exams and reports.
japanese_example: <ruby>学期末<rt>がっきまつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>課題<rt>かだい</rt></ruby>が<ruby>多<rt>おお</rt></ruby>くて<ruby>忙<rt>いそが</rt></ruby>しい。
english_example: The end of the term is busy because there are lots of assignments.

english_definition: Before; previously; can mean “earlier than X” or “formerly,” depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>以前<rt>いぜん</rt></ruby>はこの<ruby>近<rt>ちか</rt></ruby>くに<ruby>住<rt>す</rt></ruby>んでいた。
english_example: I used to live near here before.

english_definition: Smelly; stinky; an い-adjective used for unpleasant odors (also figuratively “fishy/suspicious”).
japanese_example: <ruby>靴<rt>くつ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>臭<rt>くさ</rt></ruby>いので、<ruby>外<rt>そと</rt></ruby>に<ruby>干<rt>ほ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: My shoes smelled, so I left them outside to air out.

english_definition: Past form of 転がってくる: “came rolling (toward the speaker/this side).”
japanese_example: <ruby>坂<rt>さか</rt></ruby>の<ruby>上<rt>うえ</rt></ruby>からボールが<ruby>転<rt>ころ</rt></ruby>がってきた。
english_example: A ball came rolling down from the top of the slope.

english_definition: A strong insult meaning “brute” or “cur”; rude and aggressive, used to curse someone.
japanese_example: <ruby>犬畜生<rt>いぬちくしょう</rt></ruby>めと<ruby>叫<rt>さけ</rt></ruby>んで、<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>相手<rt>あいて</rt></ruby>に<ruby>飛<rt>と</rt></ruby>び<ruby>かか</ruby>った。
english_example: Shouting “You brute!”, he lunged at the other person.

english_definition: To handle, deal with, or treat (someone/something); used both for physical handling and how someone is treated.
japanese_example: <ruby>危険<rt>きけん</rt></ruby>な<ruby>薬品<rt>やくひん</rt></ruby>は<ruby>注意<rt>ちゅうい</rt></ruby>して<ruby>扱<rt>あつか</rt></ruby>うべきだ。
english_example: Dangerous chemicals should be handled with care.

english_definition: Past tense of 扱う: “handled/dealt with/treated (someone or something).”
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はその<ruby>問題<rt>もんだい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>丁寧<rt>ていねい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>扱<rt>あつか</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He handled the issue carefully.

english_definition: Passive past of 扱う: “was handled/was treated”; commonly used for how a person was treated.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>職場<rt>しょくば</rt></ruby>で<ruby>不公平<rt>ふこうへい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>扱<rt>あつか</rt></ruby>われた。
english_example: She was treated unfairly at work.
